question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
Our function we are considering is \(\displaystyle f(x) = x^{1/3}\). Taking derivatives gives

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \frac{x^{-2/3}}{3} \\ f''(x) &= \frac{-2x^{-5/3}}{9}\end{aligned}\]

Since the linear approximation is centred about \(a = 8\) we are looking for the maximum value of \(|f''(x)| = \frac{2}{9}x^{-5/3}\) on the interval \(\displaystyle {}[7, 8]\). Since \(x^{-5/3}\) is decreasing, the maximum value is attained at \(x=7\), that is, \(M = |f''(7)|.\) Overall we find that

\[\begin{aligned} |\mathrm{Error}| \leq \frac{1}{2}M(x-a)^2 = \frac{1}{2}\cdot \frac{2}{9} 7^{-5/3}(7-8)^2 = {\color{blue} \frac{7^{-5/3}}{9}.}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html: Use the formuala \(|\text{Error}| \leq \frac{M}{2}(x-a)^2,\) where \(M > 0\), to estimate an error bound for your approximation of \(\sqrt[3]{7}\) from part (a). It will be useful to remember how to find such an \(M.\)
